title: I like Brandon Sanderson's novels, while I find Robert Jordan's a 'meh'. Where do I find a full recap of Jordan's volumes in the Wheel of Times series, so I can just jump to Sanderson's texts? - Quora

response.answer_text: Interesting stance. I enjoyed both authors, though each had their strengths and weaknesses. If you really want to get a good summary, and you want it to be meaningful and actually useful for once you start reading the series, then the best option is the Official Tor Wheel of Time Re-read series: Wheel of Time Reread, done by Leigh Butler. They have a good deal of depth and exploration of the series, which is a must considering the extreme length of Wheel of Time If for some reason you really want to skim and miss most of the good parts, then I guess technically the Wheel of Time Wikia would sort of summarize the bare bones of the plot. But at that point, you’re effectively reading condensed snippets of a 4.4 million word series, which, frankly, seems like a waste of time. If you have to, do the Tor Re-Read, then jump into Sanderson once you reach his books. It won’t be nearly as fun as reading the series from the start, but it will kind of get you there. Anything short of that, and you’re basically doing the joke summary: Wheel of time abridged, some fun for WoT fans.

Wheel of Time Reread on Tor had a great blog series. They did a re-read of the whole thing with summaries and analysis as they went. Tor in general is a great resource for Fantasy and Emily Asher Perrin’s writing on the genre is delightful. Otherwise, Wheel has an entire Companion book and if you find the original “World of Wheel” it won’t contain spoilers for the last few books.  My unasked for opinion follows. Please ignore if you just want to know where to read about the series. Honestly, I just wouldn’t do this. I can’t imagine any of the books Sanderson co-wrote resonating if I didn’t already care about the characters and the build ups are intense only if you’ve travelled the journey with the characters. It’s like watching Return of the Jedi because you like Ewoks. Or jumping into Harry Potter at The Half Blood Prince. Sure, you can roughly follow what’s going on, who’s good, who’s bad, and who needs to be smacked over the head and roasted over a slow fire, but the emotional resonance won’t be there. It won’t touch you. Also, Sanderson isn’t writing as himself, or for his usual audience. He’s writing for Jordan’s audience, building Jordan’s world, completing Jordan’s vision. That means the characters are built already, the magic is in place, and there’s no room for the double switch-back that you get with say, Maris. And “there’s always another secret” doesn’t apply here. He changes both his style and his plotting. The joins are particularly obvious in The Gathering Storm, which is caught between two authors. Overall, it’s not really Sanderson. However, if you can’t be dissuaded, read the first half of book 1, Eye of the World, which introduces almost everyone who matters, read some blogs and some of the Companion, and then be prepared to be very confused when you move onto book 12 and tiny details you don’t know suddenly matter a lot. Or just re-read Sanderson’s entire output, by which time he’ll probably have another two books out.
